title: Colores
text: Por último, hemos creado paletas de colores. Por ahora hay dos: ksnet_classic y ksnet_bright. Para visualizarlas, basta con utilizar la función color_ksnet.
code: color_ksnet("classic") color_ksnet("bright")

title: Colores
text: Para visualizar variables continuas, tenemos varias escalas disponibles. La escala predefinida está basada en el verde KSNET, pero también tenemos: Verde Amarillo Rojo Gris   Además de las escalas monocolor, tenemos dos escalas bicolor: Verde y amarillo Rojo y amarillo  Algunos ejemplos:
code: color_ksnet("verde") color_ksnet("gris") color_ksnet("verde_amarillo") ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +      geom_point() +     theme_ksnet() +     scale_color_ksnet_continuous("verde_amarillo") +     labs(title = "Escala bicolor con verde y amarillo") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point). ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +      geom_point() +     theme_ksnet() +     scale_color_ksnet_continuous("rojo_amarillo") +     labs(title = "Escala bicolor con rojo y amarillo") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Documentos
text: Con el paquete ksnet también se pueden generar plantillas para documentos que incluyan el estilo y logos de KSNET. Ahora mismo hay disponibles dos opciones: Documento de word Presentación xaringan

title: Gráficas
text: Este es un ejemplo básico que muestra cómo resolver un problema común: hacer una gráfica con datos. Empecemos con un histograma.  La función se puede usar con la pipe también. Aquí hay una gráfica de barra.  Y finalmente, scatterplots. La función viene preparada para incluir el color estándar de KSNET, así como la plantilla de gráficos. El objeto que genera es un ggplot, así que se pueden añadir títulos y etiquetas fácilmente:
code: ## Plotting a histogram of penguin bill length  ksnet_hist(penguins, bill_length_mm)  #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin). library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  ## Simple barplot penguins %>%     group_by(species) %>%     count() %>%     ksnet_bar(species, n) ## Simple scatterplot penguins %>%     ksnet_scatter(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm) +     labs(title = "Pingüinos KSNET",          subtitle = "Según con la EPA") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Gráficas
text: También podemos utilizar themes, o plantillas de gráficas.
code: ksnet_scatter(penguins, bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm) +    labs(title = "Esto es un ejemplo",        subtitle = "Y esto un subtítulo") +   theme_ksnet() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Autores y Citas
text: Octavio Medina. Autor-, mantenedor-.

title: Autores y Citas
text: Medina O (2022). ksnet: Herramientas para el día día en KSNET. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://octmedina.github.io/ksnet/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ksnet: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET},   author = {Octavio Medina},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://octmedina.github.io/ksnet/}, }

what: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
title: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
text: El objetivo del paquete ksnet es simplificar las rutinas de trabajo analítico de KSNET. El objetivo es incluir elementos como: Gráficos sencillos para análisis exploratorio de datos usando ggplot2 Funciones auxiliares para la limpieza y análisis de datos Plantillas para presentaciones, informes y resúmenes ejecutivos Plantillas para gráficas Funciones para ayudar exportar datos y resultados en formatos accesibles etcétera

title: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
text: Se puede instalar la versión en desarrollo desde GitHub con:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("octmedina/ksnet")

title: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
text: Este es un ejemplo básico que muestra cómo resolver un problema común: hacer una gráfica con datos. Empecemos con un histograma.  La función se puede usar con la pipe también. Aquí hay una gráfica de barra.  Y finalmente, scatterplots. La función viene preparada para incluir el color estándar de KSNET, así como la plantilla de gráficos. El objeto que genera es un ggplot, así que se pueden añadir títulos y etiquetas fácilmente:
code: library(ksnet) library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2)  ## Plotting a histogram of penguin bill length  ksnet_hist(penguins, bill_length_mm)  #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin). library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  ## Simple barplot penguins %>%     group_by(species) %>%     count() %>%     ksnet_bar(species, n) ## Simple scatterplot penguins %>%     ksnet_scatter(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm) +     labs(title = "Pingüinos KSNET",          subtitle = "Según con la EPA") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
text: También podemos utilizar themes, o plantillas de gráficas.
code: ksnet_scatter(penguins, bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm) +    labs(title = "Esto es un ejemplo",        subtitle = "Y esto un subtítulo") +   theme_ksnet() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
text: Por último, hemos creado paletas de colores. Por ahora hay dos: ksnet_classic y ksnet_bright. Para visualizarlas, basta con utilizar la función color_ksnet.   Este es el aspecto que tiene cuando lo combinamos con una gráfica.
code: color_ksnet("classic") color_ksnet("bright") penguins %>%     group_by(species) %>%     count() %>%     ggplot(aes(species, n, fill = species)) +    geom_col() +   labs(title = "Pingüinos una vez más",        subtitle = "Con subtítulo") +   theme_ksnet() +   scale_fill_ksnet_discrete() ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm, color = species)) +    geom_point() +   labs(title = "This is a sample plot",        subtitle = "And this is the subtitle") +   theme_ksnet() +   scale_color_ksnet_discrete() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Herramientas para el día a día en KSNET
text: Para visualizar variables continuas, tenemos varias escalas disponibles. La escala predefinida está basada en el verde KSNET, pero también tenemos: Verde Amarillo Rojo Gris    Además de las escalas monocolor, tenemos dos escalas bicolor: Verde y amarillo Rojo y amarillo  Algunos ejemplos:
code: color_ksnet("verde") color_ksnet("gris") ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +      geom_point() +     theme_ksnet() +     scale_color_ksnet_continuous("verde") +     labs(title = "Escala monocolor con verde KSNET") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point). color_ksnet("verde_amarillo") ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +      geom_point() +     theme_ksnet() +     scale_color_ksnet_continuous("verde_amarillo") +     labs(title = "Escala bicolor con verde y amarillo") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point). ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, flipper_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +      geom_point() +     theme_ksnet() +     scale_color_ksnet_continuous("rojo_amarillo") +     labs(title = "Escala bicolor con rojo y amarillo") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

title: Set KSNET caption — caption_ksnet
text: Set bottom-right plot KSNET.

title: Set KSNET caption — caption_ksnet
code: caption_ksnet(...)

title: Set KSNET caption — caption_ksnet
text: ... character vector caption information Source Notes. See Details.

title: Set KSNET caption — caption_ksnet
text: Currently, since double caption bit tricky, works come across theme_ksnet_light information supplied.#'

title: Set KSNET caption — caption_ksnet
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(mtcars,aes(mpg))+   geom_density()+   labs( caption = caption_ksnet() )   # If more caption information if supplied, must go with theme_ksnet_light ggplot(mtcars,aes(mpg))+   geom_density()+   labs( caption = caption_ksnet('Fuente: ECV') )+   theme_ksnet_light() #> Warning: Vectorized input to `element_text()` is not officially supported. #> Results may be unexpected or may change in future versions of ggplot2.

title: Add Month labels in Catalan to ggplot2 — catalan_month_label
text: breaks argument specified inside scale_x_date. See Examples.

title: Add Month labels in Catalan to ggplot2 — catalan_month_label
text: ScaleContinuousDate object ggplot.

title: Add Month labels in Catalan to ggplot2 — catalan_month_label
code: df <- data.frame(    x = seq.Date(lubridate::as_date('2020-01-01'),lubridate::as_date('2022-05-01'),                 by = '1 month'),    y = rnorm(29) ) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘lubridate’  ggplot(df, aes(x,y))+  geom_line()+  scale_x_date(breaks = '1 month', # specify step width               labels = catalan_month_label ) # add the function to label param #> Error in ggplot(df, aes(x, y)):   You're passing a function as global data. #>   Have you misspelled the `data` argument in `ggplot()`

title: Type of pair of variables — detect_pair_type
text: character vector length 1. Values can '2dummies','2num', '2fac','num_dummy' 'num_fac'.

title: Type of pair of variables — detect_pair_type
code: detect_pair_type(as.factor(mtcars$carb),as.factor(mtcars$cyl)) # '2fac' #> [1] "2fac" detect_pair_type(mtcars$am,  mtcars$vs) # '2dummies #> [1] "2dummies" detect_pair_type(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp) # '2num' #> [1] "2num" detect_pair_type(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$vs) # 'num_dummy' #> [1] "num_dummy" detect_pair_type(mtcars$mpg, as.factor(mtcars$cyl)) # 'num_fac' #> [1] "num_fac"

what: Extract data from catastro object — extract_from_catastro
title: Extract data from catastro object — extract_from_catastro
text: scraping data scrape_catastro obtained object class catastro list least two elements (parcelas inmuebles). function information can translated tibble: parcelas inmuebles well

title: Extract data from catastro object — extract_from_catastro
code: extract_from_catastro(list_scrape, which = c("parcelas", "inmuebles"))

title: Extract data from catastro object — extract_from_catastro
text: list_scrape catastro object (output scrape_catastro). Options: 'parcelas', 'inmuebles' c('parcelas','inmuebles').

title: Extract data from catastro object — extract_from_catastro
text: tibble specified information.

title: Extract data from catastro object — extract_from_catastro
code: # Real example  urls <- c("https://www1.sedecatastro.gob.es/CYCBienInmueble/OVCListaBienes.aspx?rc1=9797905&rc2=VK3799F",           "https://www1.sedecatastro.gob.es/CYCBienInmueble/OVCListaBienes.aspx?rc1=2831834&rc2=VK4723B")  address <- c('CL ARMENTEROS 44','CL ABTAO 30')  # web scraping: example_catastro <- scrape_catastro(urls,address) #> Error in scrape_catastro(urls, address): rvest and dplyr packages must be loaded  # extract information:  extract_from_catastro(example_catastro, which = 'inmuebles') #> Error in extract_from_catastro(example_catastro, which = "inmuebles"): objeto 'example_catastro' no encontrado  extract_from_catastro(example_catastro, which = 'parcelas') #> Error in extract_from_catastro(example_catastro, which = "parcelas"): objeto 'example_catastro' no encontrado  extract_from_catastro(example_catastro, c('inmuebles','parcelas')) #> Error in extract_from_catastro(example_catastro, c("inmuebles", "parcelas")): objeto 'example_catastro' no encontrado

what: Generate synthetic vectors from their sampling distributions — generate_synthetic_object
title: Generate synthetic vectors from their sampling distributions — generate_synthetic_object
text: One way creating synthetic data replicating sampling distribution variable. function can applied dataframes, numeric character/factor vectors obtain object equal length synthetic values.

title: Generate synthetic vectors from their sampling distributions — generate_synthetic_object
code: generate_synthetic_object(obj, seed = NULL, n_news = NULL)  # S3 método para default generate_synthetic_object(obj, seed = NULL, n_news = NULL)  # S3 método para numeric generate_synthetic_object(obj, seed = NULL, n_news = NULL)  # S3 método para data.frame generate_synthetic_object(obj, seed = NULL, n_news = NULL)

title: Generate synthetic vectors from their sampling distributions — generate_synthetic_object
text: obj dataframe, numeric vector character/factor vector. seed Specify seed replication desired. n_news Length new vectors. default, length input.

title: Generate synthetic vectors from their sampling distributions — generate_synthetic_object
text: object equal dimensions (n_news specified) synthetic values.

title: Generate synthetic vectors from their sampling distributions — generate_synthetic_object
Tidy association result — get_association
text: Detect pair type carry appropiate association test. can passed two vectors (x y) dataframe.

title: Tidy association result — get_association
code: get_association(   x,   y,   name_x = NULL,   name_y = NULL,   df,   pairs_to_check,   return_df )  # S3 método para default get_association(x, y, name_x = NULL, name_y = NULL)  # S3 método para data.frame get_association(df, pairs_to_check = NULL, return_df = FALSE)

title: Tidy association result — get_association
text: x vector. y vector. name_x Optional. Name x variable (character). name_y Optional. Name y variable (character). df data.frame required data. pairs_to_check NULL (default), character vector, dataframe two columns named list. return_df TRUE, passed dataframe, returned dataframe well instead named list.

title: Tidy association result — get_association
text: dataframe named list results.

title: Tidy association result — get_association
text: input dataframe, pairs_to_check specified possible combinations variables taken account. character vector variable names, pair combinations used. Besides, can dataframe two columns specifying desired pairs. Finally, can named list name variable name, element character vector names variables combine element name. See Examples.

title: Tidy association result — get_association
code: # DATA FOR THE EXAMPLES #  library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union df <- mtcars %>%  filter( carb != 6 & carb != 8 ) %>%  mutate( across(c(cyl,vs,am,gear, carb), as.factor) )  ## VECTORS ## get_association(df$mpg, df$disp) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘broom’ get_association(df$mpg, df$am) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘broom’   ## DATA.FRAMES ##  ## all columns combination get_association(df[,c(1,2,3,9)], return_df = T) #> Error: 'get_association.default' is not an exported object from 'namespace:ksnet'  ## only this variables combination get_association(df, pairs_to_check = c('cyl','disp','gear'),return_df = F ) #> Error: 'get_association.default' is not an exported object from 'namespace:ksnet'   ## only these pairs of combinations df_pairs <- data.frame( 'x'=c('cyl','disp','gear'),                         'y'= c('gear','vs','mpg'))  get_association( df, pairs_to_check = df_pairs, return_df = T ) #> Error: 'get_association.default' is not an exported object from 'namespace:ksnet'  ## for each variable the desired combinations: list_pairs <- list( 'mpg' = c('cyl','disp','vs'),                     'cyl' = c('disp','vs','am')  )  get_association( df, pairs_to_check = list_pairs, return_df = T ) #> Error: 'get_association.default' is not an exported object from 'namespace:ksnet'

title: Tidy summarise results — get_summarise
text: Detect pair type carry appropiate summarise function. can passed two vectors (x y) dataframe.

title: Tidy summarise results — get_summarise
code: get_summarise(   x,   y,   peso,   round_stats,   round_p,   name_x,   name_y,   df,   pairs_to_check )  # S3 método para default get_summarise(   x,   y,   peso = NULL,   round_stats = 3,   round_p = 3,   name_x = NULL,   name_y = NULL )  # S3 método para data.frame get_summarise(   df,   pairs_to_check = NULL,   peso = NULL,   round_stats = 3,   round_p = 3 )

title: Tidy summarise results — get_summarise
text: x vector. y vector. peso Optional. vector weights. round_stats numeric length 1. Number decimals stats. round_p numeric length 1. Number decimals proportions. name_x Optional. Name x variable (character). name_y Optional. Name y variable (character). df data.frame required data. pairs_to_check NULL (default), character vector, dataframe two columns named list.

title: Tidy summarise results — get_summarise
text: input dataframe, pairs_to_check specified possible combinations variables taken account. character vector variable names, pair combinations used. Besides, can dataframe two columns specifying desired pairs. Finally, can named list name variable name, element character vector names variables combine element name. See Examples.

title: Tidy summarise results — get_summarise

code:
x <- c("Barcelona", "Madrid", "Murcia") y <- c(115, 90, 145) z <- c(2019, 2020, 2019) mis_datos <- data.frame(provincia = x, variable = y, fecha = z) ksnet_table(mis_datos) #>
#> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #>
provinciavariablefecha
Barcelona1152019
Madrid902020
Murcia1452019
#>

what: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
title: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
text: Method imported Machine Learning techniques inferential statistics mind. Detect wich pair interaction statistically significant 'regardless' input data.

title: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
code: lm_search_interactions(   data,   vd,   vars_interactions,   controls = NULL,   n_muestras = 10,   p_muestras = 0.9,   var_to_stratify = NULL,   peso = NULL,   get_summary = TRUE )

title: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
text: data dataframe. vd Name dependent variable (character). vars_interactions character vector names variables interact betwean pairs. controls character vector names variable controls (desired) ''. Default NULL. See details information. n_muestras Number samples take data. 1 speficied, takes entire dataset. p_muestras Proportion observations keep sample. n_muestras greater 1. var_to_stratify Name variable stratify creating samples. Default NULL. peso Numeric vector sampling weights. NULL used vector ones. get_summary Logical. returned coefficient every sample just average? Default TRUE.

title: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
text: list two elements: 'outcome' dataframe results, 'formulas' showing formulas used.

title: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
text: specifying '' inf 'controls', variables present vars_interactions used every linear model.

title: Search for interactions in linear models — lm_search_interactions
code: res_temp <- lm_search_interactions( data = mtcars,                                     vd = 'mpg',                                     vars_interactions = c('cyl','disp','vs'),                                     controls = 'all',                                     n_muestras = 3,                                     p_muestras = .9,                                     get_summary = F) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘broom’ res_temp$outcome #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): objeto 'res_temp' no encontrado res_temp$formulas #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): objeto 'res_temp' no encontrado

title: Generate samples from a dataset — make_samples
text: data dataframe p Numeric 0 1. Percentage observations keep sample. var_to_stratify desired, name variable straty sampling. Default NULL. pond numeric vector sample weights. Default NULL. seed Numeric.

title: Generate samples from a dataset — make_samples
text: list dataframes.

title: Generate samples from a dataset — make_samples
code: ecv <- read_csv('ecv.csv') #> Error in read_csv("ecv.csv"): no se pudo encontrar la función "read_csv"  # Make 10 samples, 90% of observations in each one and stratify by CCAA ecv_samples <- make_samples(ecv, 10, .9, 'CCAA') #> Error in make_samples(ecv, 10, 0.9, "CCAA"): objeto 'ecv' no encontrado  # Taking into account sample weights ecv_samples <- make_samples(ecv, 10, .9, 'CCAA', ecv$factor_hogar) #> Error in make_samples(ecv, 10, 0.9, "CCAA", ecv$factor_hogar): objeto 'ecv' no encontrado

what: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
title: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
text: importing data Stata, vectors take 'haven_labelled' class specific attributes. Given class (attributes) exist R can lead errors unexpected behaviours.

title: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
code: modify_haven_labelled(obj, return_labels = TRUE)

title: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
text: obj dataframe vector return_labels Logical. Return variable values integers labels. Default TRUE (labels). new_class return_lavels set FALSE, desired class vector/variables. Choices: 'numeric', 'character' 'logical'. default converted numeric.

title: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
text: object changed class.

title: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
text: function provided changing class object. dataframe necessary previously select columns, since function detects variables need modified. importing .dta data, coerce functions .numeric .character work well principle. However, .dta transformed .rds (memory reasons) new vectors intractables functions. Thus, function designed deal type situation.

title: Adjust STATA objects to R format — modify_haven_labelled
code: # Import data ecv2020 <- haven::read.dta('ecv2020.dta') #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘haven’ # The function detects which columns must be changed ecv2020 <- modify_haven_labelled(ecv2020) #> Error in is.data.frame(obj): objeto 'ecv2020' no encontrado  # It can be applied to one variable ecv2020$situacion_hogar <- modify_haven_labelled( ecv2020$situacion_hogar ) #> Error in is.data.frame(obj): objeto 'ecv2020' no encontrado  ecv2020 <- ecv2020 %>%    mutate( situacion_hogar = modify_haven_labelled( situacion_hogar )  ) #> Error in mutate(., situacion_hogar = modify_haven_labelled(situacion_hogar)): objeto 'ecv2020' no encontrado

title: Web Scraping of Catastro — scrape_catastro
text: function designed extract information related real estates Catastro, example .

title: Web Scraping of Catastro — scrape_catastro
code: scrape_catastro(url, ID = NA_character_, i = NULL, verbose = FALSE)

title: Web Scraping of Catastro — scrape_catastro
text: url character vector variable length url. ID optional character vector unique identification real state. example, name address. internal argument url vector length greater 1. use parameter. verbose TRUE, iteration number printed console. Default set FALSE.

title: Web Scraping of Catastro — scrape_catastro
text: list two elements: first one information main real state (parcela). second element information regarding real states associated main one (inmuebles).

title: Web Scraping of Catastro — scrape_catastro
text: data related

title: Web Scraping of Catastro — scrape_catastro
code: # Real examples  url_1 <- "https://www1.sedecatastro.gob.es/CYCBienInmueble/OVCListaBienes.aspx?rc1=9797905&rc2=VK3799F" url_2 <- "https://www1.sedecatastro.gob.es/CYCBienInmueble/OVCListaBienes.aspx?rc1=2831834&rc2=VK4723B"  address_1 <- 'CL ARMENTEROS 44' address_2 <- 'CL ABTAO 30'  # web scraping the information of the first one:  scrape_catastro( url_1, address_1 ) #> Error in scrape_catastro(url_1, address_1): rvest and dplyr packages must be loaded  # web scraping the information of the two webpages:  urls <- c(url_1,url_2) address <- c(address_1,address_2)  scrape_catastro( urls, address, verbose = TRUE ) #> Error in scrape_catastro(urls, address, verbose = TRUE): rvest and dplyr packages must be loaded

title: Extract descriptive statistics between two factors — summarise_fac_fac

title: Extract descriptive statistics between two factors — summarise_fac_fac

title: Extract descriptive statistics between two factors — summarise_fac_fac
code: # DATA FOR THE EXAMPLES #  library(dplyr) df <- mtcars %>%  filter( carb != 6 & carb != 8 ) %>%  mutate( across(c(cyl,vs,am,gear, carb), as.factor) )  df$vs <- as.factor(df$vs) summarise_fac_fac( df$cyl, df$vs, peso = abs(runif(30,0.5,3)) ) #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #>   cyl   vs        N     p Desv.Est.  p_min p_max #>   <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 4     0         3 0.173     0.224 -0.565 0.91  #> 2 4     1        14 0.827     0.103  0.607 1.05  #> 3 6     0         4 0.361     0.227 -0.243 0.965 #> 4 6     1         8 0.639     0.17   0.246 1.03  #> 5 8     0        26 1         0      1     1

title: Extract descriptive statistics grouping by a factor — summarise_fac_num
code: # DATA FOR THE EXAMPLES #  library(dplyr) df <- mtcars %>%  filter( carb != 6 & carb != 8 ) %>%  mutate( across(c(cyl,vs,am,gear, carb), as.factor) )  summarise_fac_num(df$mpg, df$cyl,runif(30,0.5,1.5)) #> Error in summarise(., Min = min(y, na.rm = T), pt_25 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y,     pond, 0.25, na.rm = T), Mediana = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y,     pond, 0.5, na.rm = T), Media = weighted.mean(y, pond, na.rm = T),     pt_75 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y, pond, 0.75, na.rm = T), Max = max(y,         na.rm = T), Desv.Est. = sqrt(Hmisc::wtd.var(y, pond,         na.rm = T)), .groups = "drop"): Problem while computing `pt_25 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y, pond, 0.25, #> na.rm = T)`. #> ℹ The error occurred in group 1: cyl = 4. #> Caused by error in `loadNamespace()`: #> ! there is no package called ‘Hmisc’ summarise_fac_num(mtcars$mpg, as.factor(mtcars$cyl)) #> Error in summarise(., Min = min(y, na.rm = T), pt_25 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y,     pond, 0.25, na.rm = T), Mediana = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y,     pond, 0.5, na.rm = T), Media = weighted.mean(y, pond, na.rm = T),     pt_75 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y, pond, 0.75, na.rm = T), Max = max(y,         na.rm = T), Desv.Est. = sqrt(Hmisc::wtd.var(y, pond,         na.rm = T)), .groups = "drop"): Problem while computing `pt_25 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y, pond, 0.25, #> na.rm = T)`. #> ℹ The error occurred in group 1: cyl) = 4. #> Caused by error in `loadNamespace()`: #> ! there is no package called ‘Hmisc’ summarise_fac_num(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$am) #> Error in summarise(., Min = min(y, na.rm = T), pt_25 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y,     pond, 0.25, na.rm = T), Mediana = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y,     pond, 0.5, na.rm = T), Media = weighted.mean(y, pond, na.rm = T),     pt_75 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y, pond, 0.75, na.rm = T), Max = max(y,         na.rm = T), Desv.Est. = sqrt(Hmisc::wtd.var(y, pond,         na.rm = T)), .groups = "drop"): Problem while computing `pt_25 = Hmisc::wtd.quantile(y, pond, 0.25, #> na.rm = T)`. #> ℹ The error occurred in group 1: am = 0. #> Caused by error in `loadNamespace()`: #> ! what: Apply the ksnet theme to your graphs — theme_ksnet
title: Apply the ksnet theme to your graphs — theme_ksnet
text: Apply ksnet theme graphs

title: Apply the ksnet theme to your graphs — theme_ksnet
code: theme_ksnet()

title: Theme KSNET fot ggplots — theme_ksnet_light
text: one available ksnet themes plots. parameters just specified within theme function. argument accesible function, can combined another specific theme.

title: Theme KSNET fot ggplots — theme_ksnet_light
code: theme_ksnet_light(   legend_position = "right",   title_size = 14.5,   subtitle_size = 12.5,   x_size = 12.5,   y_size = 12.5,   axis_x_size = 12,   axis_y_size = 12,   x_vjust = 4,   remove_grid_major_y = TRUE,   remove_grid_major_x = TRUE,   is_x_date = FALSE,   plot_font = "Public Sans" )

title: Theme KSNET fot ggplots — theme_ksnet_light
text: legend_position character vector. Default right. title_size numeric. Default 14.5. subtitle_size numeric. Default 12.5. x_size numeric. Axis title size. Default 12.5. y_size numeric. Axis title size. Default 12.5. axis_x_size numeric. Axis text size. Default 12. axis_y_size numeric. Axis text size. Default 12. x_vjust numeric. Default 4. remove_grid_major_y logical. Default TRUE. remove_grid_major_x logical. Default TRUE. is_x_date x axis represents date vector set TRUE adjust vjust. font_family default Public Sants. necessary installed. See Details.

title: Theme KSNET fot ggplots — theme_ksnet_light
text: object class gg theme add existing ggplot object.

title: Theme KSNET fot ggplots — theme_ksnet_light
text: beginning script, installed Public Sans font, write following code load font: windowsFonts('Public Sans'='Public Sans')

title: Theme KSNET fot ggplots — theme_ksnet_light
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(mtcars,aes(mpg))+   geom_density()+   theme_ksnet_light() #> Warning: Vectorized input to `element_text()` is not officially supported. #> Results may be unexpected or may change in future versions of ggplot2.   ggplot(mtcars,aes(mpg))+   geom_density()+   theme_ksnet_light(remove_grid_major_x = FALSE) #> Warning: Vectorized input to `element_text()` is not officially supported. #> Results may be unexpected or may change in future versions of ggplot2.
